The findings in this work provide an understanding of beer diversity and open avenues for linking ingredient usage with fermentation profiles and flavor outcomes.

item.title: VLM-KG: Multimodal Radiology Knowledge Graph Generation
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: Vision-Language Models, Radiology, Knowledge Graphs, Multimodal, Generation
Summary: This paper introduces a novel approach for generating radiology-specific knowledge graphs using a Vision-Language Model (VLM) framework. Traditional methods struggle with the specialized language of radiology reports and the lack of domain-specific data. The proposed multimodal VLM-based framework combines radiology reports and radiographic images to enhance knowledge graph generation in radiology. By incorporating both modalities, the model outperforms existing unimodal solutions. This approach is the first of its kind in the field of radiology knowledge graph generation, addressing the limitations of previous methods. The framework is able to handle long-form radiology data efficiently and effectively, providing valuable insights and enhancing various downstream tasks in the radiology domain. <div> arXiv:2505.17042v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) have demonstrated remarkable success in natural language generation, excelling at instruction following and structured output generation. Knowledge graphs play a crucial role in radiology, serving as valuable sources of factual information and enhancing various downstream tasks. However, generating radiology-specific knowledge graphs presents significant challenges due to the specialized language of radiology reports and the limited availability of domain-specific data. Existing solutions are predominantly unimodal, meaning they generate knowledge graphs only from radiology reports while excluding radiographic images. Additionally, they struggle with long-form radiology data due to limited context length. To address these limitations, we propose a novel multimodal VLM-based framework for knowledge graph generation in radiology. Our approach outperforms previous methods and introduces the first multimodal solution for radiology knowledge graph generation.

item.title: QRA++: Quantified Reproducibility Assessment for Common Types of Results in Natural Language Processing
item.content:encoded:
reproducibility assessment, NLP, QRA++, experiments, comparability Summary: - QRA++ is introduced as a quantitative approach to assess reproducibility in NLP studies. - The approach provides continuous-valued assessments at three levels of detail. - It allows for direct comparisons of reproducibility measures across different studies. - QRA++ is grounded in the degree of similarity between experiments to set expectations. - Results from applying QRA++ to comparable experiments suggest that reproducibility depends on experiment properties, system type, and evaluation method.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17043v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Reproduction studies reported in NLP provide individual data points which in combination indicate worryingly low levels of reproducibility in the field. Because each reproduction study reports quantitative conclusions based on its own, often not explicitly stated, criteria for reproduction success/failure, the conclusions drawn are hard to interpret, compare, and learn from. In this paper, we present QRA++, a quantitative approach to reproducibility assessment that (i) produces continuous-valued degree of reproducibility assessments at three levels of granularity; (ii) utilises reproducibility measures that are directly comparable across different studies; and (iii) grounds expectations about degree of reproducibility in degree of similarity between experiments. QRA++ enables more informative reproducibility assessments to be conducted, and conclusions to be drawn about what causes reproducibility to be better/poorer. We illustrate this by applying QRA++ to three example sets of comparable experiments, revealing clear evidence that degree of reproducibility depends on similarity of experiment properties, but also system type and evaluation method.

item.title: Assessing GPT's Bias Towards Stigmatized Social Groups: An Intersectional Case Study on Nationality Prejudice and Psychophobia
item.content:encoded:
<div> nationality, biases, large language models, empathy, intersectional identity
Summary: This research delves into the ethical implications of biases present in large language models (LLMs) such as GPT-3.5/4/4o. The study examines how these biases intersect with scenarios involving American and North Korean nationalities and mental disabilities. The findings highlight significant discrepancies in empathy levels, with North Koreans facing greater negative bias, especially when mental disability is a factor. This emphasizes the need for LLMs to be developed with a more nuanced understanding of intersectional identity. <div> arXiv:2505.17045v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent studies have separately highlighted significant biases within foundational large language models (LLMs) against certain nationalities and stigmatized social groups. This research investigates the ethical implications of these biases intersecting with outputs of widely-used GPT-3.5/4/4o LLMS. Through structured prompt series, we evaluate model responses to several scenarios involving American and North Korean nationalities with various mental disabilities. Findings reveal significant discrepancies in empathy levels with North Koreans facing greater negative bias, particularly when mental disability is also a factor. This underscores the need for improvements in LLMs designed with a nuanced understanding of intersectional identity.

item.title: Assessing the Quality of AI-Generated Clinical Notes: A Validated Evaluation of a Large Language Model Scribe
item.content:encoded:
AI scribes, clinical notes, quality evaluation, physician documentation, medical specialties

Summary: Physicians in the US are using AI tools as scribes to document clinical encounters. A study compared large language model (LLM) generated notes with those from experts using the Physician Documentation Quality Instrument (PDQI9). High agreement among evaluators was found in general medicine, orthopedics, and obstetrics and gynecology, with moderate to high in pediatrics and cardiology. Gold notes scored slightly higher than Ambient notes in overall quality. The study suggests the PDQI9 tool is effective in evaluating LLM authored notes compared to human-authored ones.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17047v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In medical practices across the United States, physicians have begun implementing generative artificial intelligence (AI) tools to perform the function of scribes in order to reduce the burden of documenting clinical encounters. Despite their widespread use, no established methods exist to gauge the quality of AI scribes. To address this gap, we developed a blinded study comparing the relative performance of large language model (LLM) generated clinical notes with those from field experts based on audio-recorded clinical encounters. Quantitative metrics from the Physician Documentation Quality Instrument (PDQI9) provided a framework to measure note quality, which we adapted to assess relative performance of AI generated notes. Clinical experts spanning 5 medical specialties used the PDQI9 tool to evaluate specialist-drafted Gold notes and LLM authored Ambient notes. Two evaluators from each specialty scored notes drafted from a total of 97 patient visits. We found uniformly high inter rater agreement (RWG greater than 0.7) between evaluators in general medicine, orthopedics, and obstetrics and gynecology, and moderate (RWG 0.5 to 0.7) to high inter rater agreement in pediatrics and cardiology. We found a modest yet significant difference in the overall note quality, wherein Gold notes achieved a score of 4.25 out of 5 and Ambient notes scored 4.20 out of 5 (p = 0.04). Our findings support the use of the PDQI9 instrument as a practical method to gauge the quality of LLM authored notes, as compared to human-authored notes.

item.title: Words That Unite The World: A Unified Framework for Deciphering Central Bank Communications Globally
item.content:encoded:
<div> central banks, policy implications, monetary policy, language models, dataset
Summary: The article introduces the World Central Banks (WCB) dataset, a comprehensive monetary policy corpus from 25 central banks worldwide spanning 28 years. Three tasks are defined: Stance Detection, Temporal Classification, and Uncertainty Estimation. Benchmarking experiments on seven Pretrained Language Models and nine Large Language Models show that a model trained on aggregated data across banks outperforms individual bank data models. Rigorous evaluations and predictive tasks validate the framework's economic utility. The artifacts are accessible through HuggingFace and GitHub under the CC-BY-NC-SA 4.0 license. <div> arXiv:2505.17048v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Central banks around the world play a crucial role in maintaining economic stability. Deciphering policy implications in their communications is essential, especially as misinterpretations can disproportionately impact vulnerable populations. To address this, we introduce the World Central Banks (WCB) dataset, the most comprehensive monetary policy corpus to date, comprising over 380k sentences from 25 central banks across diverse geographic regions, spanning 28 years of historical data. After uniformly sampling 1k sentences per bank (25k total) across all available years, we annotate and review each sentence using dual annotators, disagreement resolutions, and secondary expert reviews. We define three tasks: Stance Detection, Temporal Classification, and Uncertainty Estimation, with each sentence annotated for all three. We benchmark seven Pretrained Language Models (PLMs) and nine Large Language Models (LLMs) (Zero-Shot, Few-Shot, and with annotation guide) on these tasks, running 15,075 benchmarking experiments. We find that a model trained on aggregated data across banks significantly surpasses a model trained on an individual bank's data, confirming the principle "the whole is greater than the sum of its parts." Additionally, rigorous human evaluations, error analyses, and predictive tasks validate our framework's economic utility. Our artifacts are accessible through the HuggingFace and GitHub under the CC-BY-NC-SA 4.0 license.

item.title: Gender and Positional Biases in LLM-Based Hiring Decisions: Evidence from Comparative CV/R\'esum\'e Evaluations
item.content:encoded:
bias, gender, language models, resumes, candidate selection Summary: - Large Language Models (LLMs) were found to exhibit bias in selecting candidates based on gender cues in resumes. - Despite identical qualifications, LLMs consistently favored female-named candidates across various professions. - Adding explicit gender fields to resumes increased the preference for female applicants. - Gender-neutral identifiers resulted in gender parity in candidate selection. - LLMs showed a positional bias to select the candidate listed first in the prompt. - The study highlights the need for caution in using LLMs for decision-making and questions their consistent application of reasoning.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17049v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This study examines the behavior of Large Language Models (LLMs) when evaluating professional candidates based on their resumes or curricula vitae (CVs). In an experiment involving 22 leading LLMs, each model was systematically given one job description along with a pair of profession-matched CVs, one bearing a male first name, the other a female first name, and asked to select the more suitable candidate for the job. Each CV pair was presented twice, with names swapped to ensure that any observed preferences in candidate selection stemmed from gendered names cues. Despite identical professional qualifications across genders, all LLMs consistently favored female-named candidates across 70 different professions. Adding an explicit gender field (male/female) to the CVs further increased the preference for female applicants. When gendered names were replaced with gender-neutral identifiers "Candidate A" and "Candidate B", several models displayed a preference to select "Candidate A". Counterbalancing gender assignment between these gender-neutral identifiers resulted in gender parity in candidate selection. When asked to rate CVs in isolation rather than compare pairs, LLMs assigned slightly higher average scores to female CVs overall, but the effect size was negligible. Including preferred pronouns (he/him or she/her) next to a candidate's name slightly increased the odds of the candidate being selected regardless of gender. Finally, most models exhibited a substantial positional bias to select the candidate listed first in the prompt. These findings underscore the need for caution when deploying LLMs in high-stakes autonomous decision-making contexts and raise doubts about whether LLMs consistently apply principled reasoning.

item.title: Towards Robust Evaluation of STEM Education: Leveraging MLLMs in Project-Based Learning
item.content:encoded:
multimodal data, Project-Based Learning, large language models, education, benchmark
Summary:
Project-Based Learning (PBL) involving multimodal data is essential in STEM education. Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) are being explored to enhance educational tasks. Existing benchmarks lack a free-form output structure and rigorous validation process. Automated pipelines leveraging MLLMs are limited due to model hallucination and instability. PBLBench is introduced as a benchmark to evaluate complex reasoning in educational tasks with structured evaluation criteria derived from expert-driven pairwise comparisons. Performance evaluation of 15 MLLMs/LLMs on PBLBench shows significant challenges, with the most advanced models achieving only 59% rank accuracy. PBLBench aims to spur the development of more capable AI agents to support teachers and enhance educational productivity.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17050v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Project-Based Learning (PBL) involves a variety of highly correlated multimodal data, making it a vital educational approach within STEM disciplines. With the rapid development of multimodal large language models (MLLMs), researchers have begun exploring their potential to enhance tasks such as information retrieval, knowledge comprehension, and data generation in educational settings. However, existing benchmarks fall short in providing both a free-form output structure and a rigorous human expert validation process, limiting their effectiveness in evaluating real-world educational tasks. Additionally, few methods have developed automated pipelines to assist with the complex responsibilities of teachers leveraging MLLMs, largely due to model hallucination and instability, which lead to unreliable implementation. To address this gap, we introduce PBLBench, a novel benchmark designed to evaluate complex reasoning grounded in domain-specific knowledge and long-context understanding, thereby challenging models with tasks that closely resemble those handled by human experts. To establish reliable ground truth, we adopt the Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP), utilizing expert-driven pairwise comparisons to derive structured and weighted evaluation criteria. We assess the performance of 15 leading MLLMs/LLMs using PBLBench and demonstrate that even the most advanced models achieve only 59% rank accuracy, underscoring the significant challenges presented by this benchmark. We believe PBLBench will serve as a catalyst for the development of more capable AI agents, ultimately aiming to alleviate teacher workload and enhance educational productivity.

item.title: Embedding-to-Prefix: Parameter-Efficient Personalization for Pre-Trained Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Method, Language models, Personalization, Contextual signals, Efficiency Summary: - The article introduces Embedding-to-Prefix (E2P), a method that enables personalization in large language models (LLMs) without costly fine-tuning. - E2P injects pre-computed context embeddings into an LLM's hidden representation space through a learned projection to a soft token prefix, allowing for effective personalization while keeping the backbone model frozen. - The method is evaluated across two public datasets and in a production setting, showing strong performance in dialogue personalization on Persona-Chat, contextual headline generation on PENS, and large-scale personalization for music and podcast consumption. - E2P preserves contextual signals and achieves high performance with minimal computational overhead, offering an efficient solution for contextualizing generative AI systems. - The study suggests that E2P is scalable and parameter-efficient, providing a practical approach to tailoring LLM outputs to individual users for enhanced personalization.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17051v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) excel at generating contextually relevant content. However, tailoring these outputs to individual users for effective personalization is a significant challenge. While rich user-specific information often exists as pre-existing user representations, such as embeddings learned from preferences or behaviors, current methods to leverage these for LLM personalization typically require costly fine-tuning or token-heavy prompting. We propose Embedding-to-Prefix (E2P), a parameter-efficient method that injects pre-computed context embeddings into an LLM's hidden representation space through a learned projection to a single soft token prefix. This enables effective personalization while keeping the backbone model frozen and avoiding expensive adaptation techniques. We evaluate E2P across two public datasets and in a production setting: dialogue personalization on Persona-Chat, contextual headline generation on PENS, and large-scale personalization for music and podcast consumption. Results show that E2P preserves contextual signals and achieves strong performance with minimal computational overhead, offering a scalable, efficient solution for contextualizing generative AI systems.

item.title: SpecEdge: Scalable Edge-Assisted Serving Framework for Interactive LLMs
item.content:encoded:
speculative decoding, edge-assisted inference, cost efficiency, server throughput, latency reduction Summary: SpecEdge is introduced as an edge-assisted inference framework that optimizes the serving of Large Language Models (LLMs) by leveraging consumer-grade GPUs at the edge. The framework splits LLM workloads between edge and server GPUs, reducing overall cost by 1.91x through 2.22x server throughput improvement. SpecEdge reduces inter token latency by 11.24% compared to a server-only baseline. Proactive edge drafting enables overlap of token creation and server verification, while pipeline-aware scheduling increases server-side throughput by interleaving multiple user requests. This approach introduces a scalable, cost-effective paradigm for LLM serving.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17052v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) power many modern applications, but serving them at scale remains costly and resource-intensive. Current server-centric systems overlook consumer-grade GPUs at the edge. We introduce SpecEdge, an edge-assisted inference framework that splits LLM workloads between edge and server GPUs using a speculative decoding scheme, exchanging only token outputs over the network. SpecEdge employs proactive edge drafting to overlap edge token creation with server verification and pipeline-aware scheduling that interleaves multiple user requests to increase server-side throughput. Experiments show SpecEdge enhances overall cost efficiency by 1.91x through achieving 2.22x server throughput, and reduces inter token latency by 11.24% compared to a server-only baseline, introducing a scalable, cost-effective paradigm for LLM serving.

item.title: Social preferences with unstable interactive reasoning: Large language models in economic trust games
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: large language models, social exchange, trust games, reciprocity, interactive reasoning
Summary: Large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT-4, Claude, and Bard were studied in economic trust games to understand their social exchange capabilities. LLMs showed tendencies towards trust and reciprocity, even without specific prompts. In short, one-shot interactions, LLMs displayed initial trust similar to humans. However, differences emerged in scenarios involving trust repayment and multi-round interactions, where social preferences and interactive reasoning played a significant role. LLM responses varied when prompted to adopt selfish or unselfish personas, with ChatGPT-4 excelling in unselfish or neutral personas. Claude and Bard exhibited varying levels of trust and reciprocity compared to humans. When given selfish personas, all LLMs displayed lower social behavior. Interactive reasoning in LLMs' responses seemed random, with some improvements noted when ChatGPT-4 responded as selfish or unselfish. <div> arXiv:2505.17053v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: While large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable capabilities in understanding human languages, this study explores how they translate this understanding into social exchange contexts that capture certain essences of real world human interactions. Three LLMs - ChatGPT-4, Claude, and Bard - were placed in economic trust games where players balance self-interest with trust and reciprocity, making decisions that reveal their social preferences and interactive reasoning abilities. Our study shows that LLMs deviate from pure self-interest and exhibit trust and reciprocity even without being prompted to adopt a specific persona. In the simplest one-shot interaction, LLMs emulated how human players place trust at the beginning of such a game. Larger human-machine divergences emerged in scenarios involving trust repayment or multi-round interactions, where decisions were influenced by both social preferences and interactive reasoning. LLMs responses varied significantly when prompted to adopt personas like selfish or unselfish players, with the impact outweighing differences between models or game types. Response of ChatGPT-4, in an unselfish or neutral persona, resembled the highest trust and reciprocity, surpassing humans, Claude, and Bard. Claude and Bard displayed trust and reciprocity levels that sometimes exceeded and sometimes fell below human choices. When given selfish personas, all LLMs showed lower trust and reciprocity than humans. Interactive reasoning to the actions of counterparts or changing game mechanics appeared to be random rather than stable, reproducible characteristics in the response of LLMs, though some improvements were observed when ChatGPT-4 responded in selfish or unselfish personas.

item.title: METHOD: Modular Efficient Transformer for Health Outcome Discovery
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: transformer architectures, healthcare, clinical sequence modelling, patient-aware attention mechanism, MIMIC-IV database

Summary: The paper introduces a new transformer architecture called Modular Efficient Transformer for Health Outcome Discovery (METHOD) designed for clinical sequence modelling in electronic health records. METHOD integrates patient-aware attention mechanism, adaptive sliding window attention scheme, and a U-Net inspired architecture with dynamic skip connections. It outperforms the state-of-the-art ETHOS model in predicting high-severity cases on the MIMIC-IV database. METHOD maintains stable performance across varying inference lengths, crucial for clinical deployment. Analysis of embeddings shows METHOD preserves clinical hierarchies and relationships between medical concepts. This advancement in transformer architectures optimized for healthcare applications offers more accurate predictions while ensuring computational efficiency.
arXiv:2505.17054v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in transformer architectures have revolutionised natural language processing, but their application to healthcare domains presents unique challenges. Patient timelines are characterised by irregular sampling, variable temporal dependencies, and complex contextual relationships that differ substantially from traditional language tasks. This paper introduces \METHOD~(Modular Efficient Transformer for Health Outcome Discovery), a novel transformer architecture specifically designed to address the challenges of clinical sequence modelling in electronic health records. \METHOD~integrates three key innovations: (1) a patient-aware attention mechanism that prevents information leakage whilst enabling efficient batch processing; (2) an adaptive sliding window attention scheme that captures multi-scale temporal dependencies; and (3) a U-Net inspired architecture with dynamic skip connections for effective long sequence processing. Evaluations on the MIMIC-IV database demonstrate that \METHOD~consistently outperforms the state-of-the-art \ETHOS~model, particularly in predicting high-severity cases that require urgent clinical intervention. \METHOD~exhibits stable performance across varying inference lengths, a crucial feature for clinical deployment where patient histories vary significantly in length. Analysis of learned embeddings reveals that \METHOD~better preserves clinical hierarchies and relationships between medical concepts. These results suggest that \METHOD~represents a significant advancement in transformer architectures optimised for healthcare applications, providing more accurate and clinically relevant predictions whilst maintaining computational efficiency.

item.title: Enhancing Mathematics Learning for Hard-of-Hearing Students Through Real-Time Palestinian Sign Language Recognition: A New Dataset
item.content:encoded:
Palestinian Sign Language, mathematics education, hard-of-hearing students, artificial intelligence, gesture recognition

Summary: The study focuses on improving mathematics education accessibility for hard-of-hearing students by developing a Palestinian Sign Language (PSL) recognition system using advanced artificial intelligence techniques. A custom dataset of 41 mathematical gesture classes recorded by PSL experts was created to train a Vision Transformer ViTModel for gesture classification. The model achieved an accuracy of 97.59%, showcasing its precision in recognizing mathematical signs accurately. This research underscores the importance of deep learning in creating intelligent educational tools that assist hard-of-hearing students in understanding mathematics better. By offering AI-driven interactive solutions, this work signifies a crucial advancement towards inclusive digital integration in specialized learning environments. The dataset is available on Hugging Face, providing valuable resources for further research and development in this field.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17055v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The study aims to enhance mathematics education accessibility for hard-of-hearing students by developing an accurate Palestinian sign language PSL recognition system using advanced artificial intelligence techniques. Due to the scarcity of digital resources for PSL, a custom dataset comprising 41 mathematical gesture classes was created, and recorded by PSL experts to ensure linguistic accuracy and domain specificity. To leverage state-of-the-art-computer vision techniques, a Vision Transformer ViTModel was fine-tuned for gesture classification. The model achieved an accuracy of 97.59%, demonstrating its effectiveness in recognizing mathematical signs with high precision and reliability. This study highlights the role of deep learning in developing intelligent educational tools that bridge the learning gap for hard-of-hearing students by providing AI-driven interactive solutions to enhance mathematical comprehension. This work represents a significant step toward innovative and inclusive frosting digital integration in specialized learning environments. The dataset is hosted on Hugging Face at https://huggingface.co/datasets/fidaakh/STEM_data.

item.title: Are LLMs Ready for English Standardized Tests? A Benchmarking and Elicitation Perspective
item.content:encoded:
transforming education, AI, large language models, standardized test preparation, ESTBOOK Summary: - AI, specifically large language models (LLMs), is revolutionizing education by enhancing learning experiences and supporting standardized test preparation. - The study focuses on English Standardized Tests (ESTs) and evaluates LLMs' ability to generate accurate solutions for diverse question types. - ESTBOOK, a benchmark, includes 29 question types from five widely recognized tests across various modalities. - The evaluation assesses the accuracy and inference efficiency of LLMs, as well as proposes a framework to breakdown EST questions into specific solution steps. - Findings provide insights into LLMs' capabilities in educational settings and suggest strategies to enhance their reliability as intelligent tutoring systems.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17056v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: AI is transforming education by enabling powerful tools that enhance learning experiences. Among recent advancements, large language models (LLMs) hold particular promise for revolutionizing how learners interact with educational content. In this work, we investigate the potential of LLMs to support standardized test preparation by focusing on English Standardized Tests (ESTs). Specifically, we assess their ability to generate accurate and contextually appropriate solutions across a diverse set of EST question types. We introduce ESTBOOK, a comprehensive benchmark designed to evaluate the capabilities of LLMs in solving EST questions. ESTBOOK aggregates five widely recognized tests, encompassing 29 question types and over 10,576 questions across multiple modalities, including text, images, audio, tables, and mathematical symbols. Using ESTBOOK, we systematically evaluate both the accuracy and inference efficiency of LLMs. Additionally, we propose a breakdown analysis framework that decomposes complex EST questions into task-specific solution steps. This framework allows us to isolate and assess LLM performance at each stage of the reasoning process. Evaluation findings offer insights into the capability of LLMs in educational contexts and point toward targeted strategies for improving their reliability as intelligent tutoring systems.

item.title: DO-RAG: A Domain-Specific QA Framework Using Knowledge Graph-Enhanced Retrieval-Augmented Generation
item.content:encoded:
knowledge graph, retrieval-augmented generation, hybrid QA framework, structured relationships, hallucination mitigation Summary: DO-RAG is a novel hybrid QA framework that combines multi-level knowledge graph construction with semantic vector retrieval to enhance context recall and reasoning consistency. It utilizes an agentic chain-of-thought architecture to extract structured relationships from unstructured documents and generate dynamic knowledge graphs. At query time, DO-RAG integrates graph and vector retrieval results to provide context-aware responses, with grounded refinement to mitigate hallucinations. Experimental results in database and electrical domains demonstrate near-perfect recall and high answer relevancy, outperforming baseline frameworks by up to 33.38%. DO-RAG offers traceability, adaptability, and performance efficiency, providing a reliable foundation for scalable, high-precision QA across multiple domains.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17058v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Domain-specific QA systems require not just generative fluency but high factual accuracy grounded in structured expert knowledge. While recent Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) frameworks improve context recall, they struggle with integrating heterogeneous data and maintaining reasoning consistency. To address these challenges, we propose DO-RAG, a scalable and customizable hybrid QA framework that integrates multi-level knowledge graph construction with semantic vector retrieval. Our system employs a novel agentic chain-of-thought architecture to extract structured relationships from unstructured, multimodal documents, constructing dynamic knowledge graphs that enhance retrieval precision. At query time, DO-RAG fuses graph and vector retrieval results to generate context-aware responses, followed by hallucination mitigation via grounded refinement. Experimental evaluations in the database and electrical domains show near-perfect recall and over 94% answer relevancy, with DO-RAG outperforming baseline frameworks by up to 33.38%. By combining traceability, adaptability, and performance efficiency, DO-RAG offers a reliable foundation for multi-domain, high-precision QA at scale.

item.title: Medalyze: Lightweight Medical Report Summarization Application Using FLAN-T5-Large
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Medalyze, AI-powered application, medical texts, FLAN-T5-Large models, information accessibility Summary: Medalyze is an AI-powered application that aims to enhance the comprehension of medical texts using specialized FLAN-T5-Large models. These models are fine-tuned for summarizing medical reports, extracting health issues from patient-doctor conversations, and identifying key questions in passages. Deployed across web and mobile platforms with real-time inference, Medalyze leverages scalable API and YugabyteDB. Experimental evaluations show that Medalyze outperforms GPT-4 in domain-specific tasks like summarization, based on metrics such as BLEU, ROUGE-L, BERTScore, and SpaCy Similarity. The system provides a practical, privacy-preserving, and lightweight solution for improving information accessibility in healthcare.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17059v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Understanding medical texts presents significant challenges due to complex terminology and context-specific language. This paper introduces Medalyze, an AI-powered application designed to enhance the comprehension of medical texts using three specialized FLAN-T5-Large models. These models are fine-tuned for (1) summarizing medical reports, (2) extracting health issues from patient-doctor conversations, and (3) identifying the key question in a passage. Medalyze is deployed across a web and mobile platform with real-time inference, leveraging scalable API and YugabyteDB. Experimental evaluations demonstrate the system's superior summarization performance over GPT-4 in domain-specific tasks, based on metrics like BLEU, ROUGE-L, BERTScore, and SpaCy Similarity. Medalyze provides a practical, privacy-preserving, and lightweight solution for improving information accessibility in healthcare.

item.title: SALMONN-omni: A Standalone Speech LLM without Codec Injection for Full-duplex Conversation
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: full-duplex, speech LLM, dynamic thinking, reinforcement learning, conversational systems Summary: SALMONN-omni is introduced as a standalone full-duplex speech Language Model (LLM) that eliminates the need for audio codecs in its token space. It incorporates a dynamic thinking mechanism within the LLM backbone to determine when to switch between speaking and listening states. Experimental results on spoken question answering and open-domain dialogue tasks demonstrate that SALMONN-omni outperforms existing full-duplex models, achieving a relative performance improvement of at least 30%. Despite using less training data, it competes favorably with half-duplex and turn-based systems. The model excels in complex conversational scenarios, including turn-taking, backchanneling, echo cancellation, and context-dependent barge-in, with further enhancements through reinforcement learning. Demo conversations showcasing the capabilities of SALMONN-omni can be found in the provided repository. Summary:

SALMONN-omni is a single, standalone full-duplex speech LLM that operates without audio codecs in its token space. It incorporates a dynamic thinking mechanism to transition between speaking and listening states. Experimental results show a 30% relative performance improvement over existing full-duplex models and competitive performance with half-duplex and turn-based systems. The model excels in complex conversational scenarios like turn-taking, backchanneling, echo cancellation, and context-dependent barge-in. Further enhancements are achieved through reinforcement learning. Demo conversations are available in the provided repository.
arXiv:2505.17060v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In order to enable fluid and natural human-machine speech interaction, existing full-duplex conversational systems often adopt modular architectures with auxiliary components such as voice activity detectors, interrupters, conversation state predictors, or multiple LLMs. These systems, however, suffer from error accumulation across modules and struggle with key challenges such as context-dependent barge-in and echo cancellation. Recent approaches, most notably Moshi, simplify the pipeline by injecting audio codecs into the token space of a single LLM. However, such methods still incur significant performance degradation when operating on the speech rather than text modality. In this paper, we introduce SALMONN-omni, the first single, standalone full-duplex speech LLM that operates without audio codecs in its token space. It features a novel dynamic thinking mechanism within the LLM backbone, enabling the model to learn when to transition between speaking and listening states. Experiments on widely used benchmarks for spoken question answering and open-domain dialogue show that SALMONN-omni achieves at least 30\% relative performance improvement over existing open-source full-duplex models and performs highly competitively to half-duplex and turn-based systems, despite using substantially less training data. Moreover, SALMONN-omni demonstrates strong performance in complex conversational scenarios, including turn-taking, backchanneling, echo cancellation and context-dependent barge-in, with further improvements achieved through reinforcement learning. Some demo conversations between user and SALMONN-omni are provided in the following repository https://github.com/bytedance/SALMONN.

item.title: Mixture of Decoding: An Attention-Inspired Adaptive Decoding Strategy to Mitigate Hallucinations in Large Vision-Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Vision-Language Models, hallucination mitigation, decoding strategies, attention, benchmarks Summary: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have shown impressive capabilities in various visual tasks but are plagued by hallucination issues. To tackle this problem, a novel approach called Mixture of Decoding (MoD) is proposed. MoD dynamically adjusts decoding strategies by evaluating the model's attention on image tokens. It measures consistency between outputs from original and attended image tokens to determine attention correctness. If outputs are consistent, MoD amplifies critical information; if inconsistent, it suppresses misleading information. Extensive experiments show that MoD outperforms existing methods in mitigating hallucinations in LVLMs across multiple benchmarks. The code for MoD is available at https://github.com/xlchen0205/MoD. Summary:
Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) face challenges with hallucinations, but a novel approach called Mixture of Decoding (MoD) offers a solution. MoD dynamically adjusts decoding strategies based on attention evaluation, distinguishing between correct and erroneous focus. It amplifies critical information with consistent outputs and suppresses misleading data with inconsistent outputs. Extensive experiments demonstrate MoD's effectiveness in mitigating hallucinations in LVLMs across various benchmarks. The code for MoD can be found at https://github.com/xlchen0205/MoD.
arXiv:2505.17061v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have exhibited impressive capabilities across various visual tasks, yet they remain hindered by the persistent challenge of hallucinations. To address this critical issue, we propose Mixture of Decoding (MoD), a novel approach for hallucination mitigation that dynamically adapts decoding strategies by evaluating the correctness of the model's attention on image tokens. Specifically, MoD measures the consistency between outputs generated from the original image tokens and those derived from the model's attended image tokens, to distinguish the correctness aforementioned. If the outputs are consistent, indicating correct attention, MoD employs a complementary strategy to amplify critical information. Conversely, if the outputs are inconsistent, suggesting erroneous attention, MoD utilizes a contrastive strategy to suppress misleading information. Extensive experiments demonstrate that MoD significantly outperforms existing decoding methods across multiple mainstream benchmarks, effectively mitigating hallucinations in LVLMs. The code is available at https://github.com/xlchen0205/MoD.

item.title: Synthetic Data RL: Task Definition Is All You Need
item.content:encoded:
framework, reinforcement learning, synthetic data, model adaptation, scalability Summary: The article introduces Synthetic Data RL, a framework for reinforcement learning that fine-tunes models using only synthetic data generated from a task definition. The method generates question-answer pairs, adjusts question difficulty based on model solvability, and selects questions for RL training based on model pass rates. Results show significant improvements over base models on various tasks such as GSM8K, MATH, GPQA, MedQA, CQA (law), and CFA (finance). The approach outperforms supervised fine-tuning and nearly matches RL with full human data, with minimal added value from human demonstrations. By reducing the reliance on human-labeled data, Synthetic Data RL enables scalable and efficient model adaptation through reinforcement learning. The code and demos for this method are available on GitHub for further exploration and implementation.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17063v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) is a powerful way to adapt foundation models to specialized tasks, but its reliance on large-scale human-labeled data limits broad adoption. We introduce Synthetic Data RL, a simple and general framework that reinforcement fine-tunes models using only synthetic data generated from a task definition. Our method first generates question and answer pairs from the task definition and retrieved documents, then adapts the difficulty of the question based on model solvability, and selects questions using the average pass rate of the model across samples for RL training. On Qwen-2.5-7B, our method achieves a 29.2% absolute improvement over the base model on GSM8K (+2.9 pp vs. instruction-tuned, +6.6 pp vs. Self-Instruct), 8.7% on MATH, 13.1% on GPQA (+7.0 pp vs. SynthLLM), 8.9% on MedQA, 17.7% on CQA (law) and 13.7% on CFA (finance). It surpasses supervised fine-tuning under the same data budget and nearly matches RL with full human data across datasets (e.g., +17.2 pp on GSM8K). Adding 100 human demonstrations improves the performance of GSM8K only by 0.4 pp, showing a limited added value. By reducing human data annotation, Synthetic Data RL enables scalable and efficient RL-based model adaptation. Code and demos are available at https://github.com/gydpku/Data_Synthesis_RL/.

item.title: Decoding Rarity: Large Language Models in the Diagnosis of Rare Diseases
item.content:encoded:
AI, rare diseases, LLMs, multimodal data integration, diagnosis Summary: Recent advancements in artificial intelligence, specifically large language models (LLMs), have shown great potential in revolutionizing rare disease research. This survey delves into the integration of LLMs in rare disease analysis, emphasizing the use of textual data to reveal crucial insights for diagnosis, treatment, and patient care. While current research mostly focuses on textual data, the incorporation of multimodal data, such as genetic, imaging, and electronic health records, holds promise for future exploration. Key studies demonstrate how LLMs can identify and extract medical information, create intelligent conversational agents for patient interaction, and facilitate accurate diagnoses. Challenges like data privacy, model transparency, and the necessity of inclusive data sets are also discussed. The article includes an experimental section showcasing the use of multiple LLMs and structured questionnaires for diagnostic purposes across various diseases. Future perspectives envision the evolution of LLMs into truly multimodal platforms, encompassing diverse data types to enhance the understanding of rare diseases and improve clinical outcomes.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17065v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent advances in artificial intelligence, particularly large language models LLMs, have shown promising capabilities in transforming rare disease research. This survey paper explores the integration of LLMs in the analysis of rare diseases, highlighting significant strides and pivotal studies that leverage textual data to uncover insights and patterns critical for diagnosis, treatment, and patient care. While current research predominantly employs textual data, the potential for multimodal data integration combining genetic, imaging, and electronic health records stands as a promising frontier. We review foundational papers that demonstrate the application of LLMs in identifying and extracting relevant medical information, simulating intelligent conversational agents for patient interaction, and enabling the formulation of accurate and timely diagnoses. Furthermore, this paper discusses the challenges and ethical considerations inherent in deploying LLMs, including data privacy, model transparency, and the need for robust, inclusive data sets. As part of this exploration, we present a section on experimentation that utilizes multiple LLMs alongside structured questionnaires, specifically designed for diagnostic purposes in the context of different diseases. We conclude with future perspectives on the evolution of LLMs towards truly multimodal platforms, which would integrate diverse data types to provide a more comprehensive understanding of rare diseases, ultimately fostering better outcomes in clinical settings.

item.title: Unveil Multi-Picture Descriptions for Multilingual Mild Cognitive Impairment Detection via Contrastive Learning
item.content:encoded:
contrastive learning, multilingual speakers, mild cognitive impairment, multilingual, detection Summary: - The study addresses the challenge of detecting Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI) from picture descriptions, particularly in multilingual and multiple picture settings. - The proposed framework consists of three components: enhancing discriminative representation learning through supervised contrastive learning, incorporating the image modality, and utilizing a Product of Experts strategy to reduce spurious correlations and overfitting. - The framework significantly improves MCI detection performance, achieving a 7.1% increase in Unweighted Average Recall (UAR) and a 2.9% increase in F1 score compared to the text unimodal baseline. - The contrastive learning component particularly benefits the text modality over speech. - These results demonstrate the effectiveness of the framework in multilingual and multi-picture MCI detection.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17067v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Detecting Mild Cognitive Impairment from picture descriptions is critical yet challenging, especially in multilingual and multiple picture settings. Prior work has primarily focused on English speakers describing a single picture (e.g., the 'Cookie Theft'). The TAUKDIAL-2024 challenge expands this scope by introducing multilingual speakers and multiple pictures, which presents new challenges in analyzing picture-dependent content. To address these challenges, we propose a framework with three components: (1) enhancing discriminative representation learning via supervised contrastive learning, (2) involving image modality rather than relying solely on speech and text modalities, and (3) applying a Product of Experts (PoE) strategy to mitigate spurious correlations and overfitting. Our framework improves MCI detection performance, achieving a +7.1% increase in Unweighted Average Recall (UAR) (from 68.1% to 75.2%) and a +2.9% increase in F1 score (from 80.6% to 83.5%) compared to the text unimodal baseline. Notably, the contrastive learning component yields greater gains for the text modality compared to speech. These results highlight our framework's effectiveness in multilingual and multi-picture MCI detection.

item.title: Predictively Combatting Toxicity in Health-related Online Discussions through Machine Learning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: user toxicity, online discussions, health-related, collaborative filtering, machine learning
Summary: - The study focuses on combatting user toxicity in health-related online discussions, which can lead to social conflict and promotion of dangerous behaviors. - Current approaches involve detecting and removing toxic comments, but these methods can be counterproductive. - The study proposes a predictive approach to combat user toxicity, anticipating where a user may interact toxically. - Using Collaborative Filtering-based Machine Learning, the researchers predict toxicity in COVID-related conversations on Reddit with over 80% accuracy. - This predictive model can help prevent the pairing of conflicting users and subcommunities, ultimately promoting healthier online discussions. Summary:
arXiv:2505.17068v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: In health-related topics, user toxicity in online discussions frequently becomes a source of social conflict or promotion of dangerous, unscientific behaviour; common approaches for battling it include different forms of detection, flagging and/or removal of existing toxic comments, which is often counterproductive for platforms and users alike. In this work, we propose the alternative of combatting user toxicity predictively, anticipating where a user could interact toxically in health-related online discussions. Applying a Collaborative Filtering-based Machine Learning methodology, we predict the toxicity in COVID-related conversations between any user and subcommunity of Reddit, surpassing 80% predictive performance in relevant metrics, and allowing us to prevent the pairing of conflicting users and subcommunities.

item.title: Improving endpoint detection in end-to-end streaming ASR for conversational speech
item.content:encoded:
Endpointing, Transducer-based ASR, Delayed emission, Speech activity detection, User experience

Summary: This paper discusses the importance of ASR endpointing (EP) in enhancing user experience in human-machine conversations. The focus is on addressing the delayed emission issue in transducer-based ASR (T-ASR). The proposed method introduces an end-of-word token and a delay penalty to mitigate delayed emission, improving the accuracy of EP. Additionally, a reliable frame-level speech activity detection using an auxiliary network is employed to tackle EP delays. Experimental evaluations on Switchboard conversational speech corpus demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed methods in comparison to delay penalty techniques. Overall, the study emphasizes the significance of timely and accurate EP in ensuring seamless communication between users and ASR systems, ultimately enhancing the overall user experience.
arXiv:2505.17070v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: ASR endpointing (EP) plays a major role in delivering a good user experience in products supporting human or artificial agents in human-human/machine conversations. Transducer-based ASR (T-ASR) is an end-to-end (E2E) ASR modelling technique preferred for streaming. A major limitation of T-ASR is delayed emission of ASR outputs, which could lead to errors or delays in EP. Inaccurate EP will cut the user off while speaking, returning incomplete transcript while delays in EP will increase the perceived latency, degrading the user experience. We propose methods to improve EP by addressing delayed emission along with EP mistakes. To address the delayed emission problem, we introduce an end-of-word token at the end of each word, along with a delay penalty. The EP delay is addressed by obtaining a reliable frame-level speech activity detection using an auxiliary network. We apply the proposed methods on Switchboard conversational speech corpus and evaluate it against a delay penalty method.

item.title: What's in a prompt? Language models encode literary style in prompt embeddings
item.content:encoded:
latent space, language models, transformer layers, embeddings, stylistic features Summary: - Large language models use high-dimensional latent spaces to encode textual information and process it with transformer layers. - The study focuses on how information from entire prompts condenses into individual embeddings in deep representations. - Analysis using literary pieces shows that intangible aspects of prompts are contained in deep representations. - Short excerpts from different novels separate in the latent space regardless of next-token predictions, indicating stylistic features encoded in embeddings. - Ensembles from books by the same authors are more entangled than across authors, suggesting that embeddings encode stylistic features.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17071v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models use high-dimensional latent spaces to encode and process textual information. Much work has investigated how the conceptual content of words translates into geometrical relationships between their vector representations. Fewer studies analyze how the cumulative information of an entire prompt becomes condensed into individual embeddings under the action of transformer layers. We use literary pieces to show that information about intangible, rather than factual, aspects of the prompt are contained in deep representations. We observe that short excerpts (10 - 100 tokens) from different novels separate in the latent space independently from what next-token prediction they converge towards. Ensembles from books from the same authors are much more entangled than across authors, suggesting that embeddings encode stylistic features. This geometry of style may have applications for authorship attribution and literary analysis, but most importantly reveals the sophistication of information processing and compression accomplished by language models.

item.title: Mechanistic Interpretability of GPT-like Models on Summarization Tasks
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: GPT-like models, summarization tasks, interpretability framework, attention patterns, LoRA adaptation Summary: This paper introduces an interpretability framework for analyzing how GPT-like models adapt to summarization tasks. The study focuses on differential analysis between pre-trained and fine-tuned models, identifying specific layers and attention heads that undergo significant transformation during summarization. The research reveals that middle layers, particularly layers 2, 3, and 5, experience the most significant changes, with a shift toward focused information selection observed in 62% of attention heads. Targeted LoRA adaptation of these identified circuits leads to improved performance in summarization tasks with fewer training epochs required. By bridging the gap between black-box evaluation and mechanistic understanding, the study provides valuable insights into how neural networks handle information selection and compression in summarization processes.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17073v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Mechanistic interpretability research seeks to reveal the inner workings of large language models, yet most work focuses on classification or generative tasks rather than summarization. This paper presents an interpretability framework for analyzing how GPT-like models adapt to summarization tasks. We conduct differential analysis between pre-trained and fine-tuned models, quantifying changes in attention patterns and internal activations. By identifying specific layers and attention heads that undergo significant transformation, we locate the "summarization circuit" within the model architecture. Our findings reveal that middle layers (particularly 2, 3, and 5) exhibit the most dramatic changes, with 62% of attention heads showing decreased entropy, indicating a shift toward focused information selection. We demonstrate that targeted LoRA adaptation of these identified circuits achieves significant performance improvement over standard LoRA fine-tuning while requiring fewer training epochs. This work bridges the gap between black-box evaluation and mechanistic understanding, providing insights into how neural networks perform information selection and compression during summarization.

item.title: Semi-Clairvoyant Scheduling of Speculative Decoding Requests to Minimize LLM Inference Latency
item.content:encoded:
Scheduling, Large Language Model, Inference, Speculative Decoding, Execution Time
Summary:
The paper introduces a new request scheduling algorithm, LAPS-SD, for Large Language Model (LLM) inference with speculative decoding. The algorithm aims to minimize average inference latency by adaptively scheduling requests based on their features during decoding. LAPS-SD addresses the challenge of uncertain execution time in inference requests, considering both output length and token acceptance rate of the LLM for accurate estimation. It utilizes multiple priority queues to manage dynamic token acceptance rates and allows request execution preemption. Once the token acceptance rate stabilizes, LAPS-SD can accurately estimate execution time and optimize request scheduling. Experimental results demonstrate a significant reduction of approximately 39% in inference latency compared to existing scheduling methods, showcasing the effectiveness of LAPS-SD in improving the efficiency of LLM inference serving systems.
arXiv:2505.17074v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Speculative decoding accelerates Large Language Model (LLM) inference by employing a small speculative model (SSM) to generate multiple candidate tokens and verify them using the LLM in parallel. This technique has been widely integrated into LLM inference serving systems. However, inference requests typically exhibit uncertain execution time, which poses a significant challenge of efficiently scheduling requests in these systems. Existing work estimates execution time based solely on predicted output length, which could be inaccurate because execution time depends on both output length and token acceptance rate of verification by the LLM. In this paper, we propose a semi-clairvoyant request scheduling algorithm called Least-Attained/Perceived-Service for Speculative Decoding (LAPS-SD). Given a number of inference requests, LAPS-SD can effectively minimize average inference latency by adaptively scheduling requests according to their features during decoding. When the token acceptance rate is dynamic and execution time is difficult to estimate, LAPS-SD maintains multiple priority queues and allows request execution preemption across different queues. Once the token acceptance rate becomes stable, LAPS-SD can accurately estimate the execution time and schedule requests accordingly. Extensive experiments show that LAPS-SD reduces inference latency by approximately 39\% compared to state-of-the-art scheduling methods.

item.title: Development and Validation of Engagement and Rapport Scales for Evaluating User Experience in Multimodal Dialogue Systems
item.content:encoded:
Engagement, Rapport, User experience, Multimodal dialogue systems, Foreign language learning Summary: The study developed and validated two scales of engagement and rapport to assess user experience quality with multimodal dialogue systems in foreign language learning. The scales were based on theories from various fields. Japanese learners of English engaged in tasks with human tutors and a dialog agent, responding to the scales afterward. Cronbach's alpha and confirmatory factor analyses were used to test validity and reliability. Comparison of scores between human tutors and the dialog agent showed the scales effectively captured differences in dialogue experience quality. The scales were successful in evaluating engagement and rapport in dialogue with human interlocutors versus a dialogue agent in a variety of aspects.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17075v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This study aimed to develop and validate two scales of engagement and rapport to evaluate the user experience quality with multimodal dialogue systems in the context of foreign language learning. The scales were designed based on theories of engagement in educational psychology, social psychology, and second language acquisition.Seventy-four Japanese learners of English completed roleplay and discussion tasks with trained human tutors and a dialog agent. After each dialogic task was completed, they responded to the scales of engagement and rapport. The validity and reliability of the scales were investigated through two analyses. We first conducted analysis of Cronbach's alpha coefficient and a series of confirmatory factor analyses to test the structural validity of the scales and the reliability of our designed items. We then compared the scores of engagement and rapport between the dialogue with human tutors and the one with a dialogue agent. The results revealed that our scales succeeded in capturing the difference in the dialogue experience quality between the human interlocutors and the dialogue agent from multiple perspectives.

item.title: Impact of Frame Rates on Speech Tokenizer: A Case Study on Mandarin and English
item.content:encoded:
keywords: speech tokenizer, frame rate, Mandarin, English, automatic speech recognition Summary:

This study explores the impact of frame rates on speech tokenization for Mandarin and English languages. The research investigates how varying frame rates affect speech tokenization and evaluates semantic tokens in speech recognition tasks. The findings indicate that frame rate variations influence speech tokenization differently for each language, emphasizing the connection between frame rates, phonetic density, and language-specific acoustic features. The results offer insights into optimizing frame rate selection for speech tokenizers, with implications for automatic speech recognition, text-to-speech, and other speech-related applications.
arXiv:2505.17076v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The speech tokenizer plays a crucial role in recent speech tasks, generally serving as a bridge between speech signals and language models. While low-frame-rate codecs are widely employed as speech tokenizers, the impact of frame rates on speech tokens remains underexplored. In this study, we investigate how varying frame rates affect speech tokenization by examining Mandarin and English, two typologically distinct languages. We encode speech at different frame rates and evaluate the resulting semantic tokens in the speech recognition task. Our findings reveal that frame rate variations influence speech tokenization differently for each language, highlighting the interplay between frame rates, phonetic density, and language-specific acoustic features. The results provide insights into optimizing frame rate selection for speech tokenizers, with implications for automatic speech recognition, text-to-speech, and other speech-related applications.

item.title: GloSS over Toxicity: Understanding and Mitigating Toxicity in LLMs via Global Toxic Subspace
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: toxicity generation, Large Language Models, Feed-Forward Network, toxic subspace, GloSS Summary: This paper explores the mechanisms of toxicity creation in Large Language Models (LLMs) and introduces a novel detoxification method called GloSS (Global Toxic Subspace Suppression). Previous research focused on the Feed-Forward Network (FFN) as the source of toxicity, but the authors reveal that the global toxic subspace provides a more comprehensive representation of toxic regions in the model. GloSS consists of four stages and effectively mitigates toxicity by identifying and eliminating the global toxic subspace from the FFN parameters. The experiments conducted on various LLMs demonstrate that GloSS achieves superior detoxification performance while maintaining the model's overall capabilities. Importantly, GloSS does not require extensive data or retraining of the model, making it a lightweight and efficient solution for addressing toxicity in LLMs.

Summary: This paper delves into the root causes of toxicity in Large Language Models, presenting GloSS as a groundbreaking approach to detoxify models by targeting the global toxic subspace within the Feed-Forward Network. The proposed method outperforms existing techniques, effectively reducing toxicity without compromising the models' general capabilities, and proving to be a practical solution that does not necessitate extensive data or model retraining.
arXiv:2505.17078v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper investigates the underlying mechanisms of toxicity generation in Large Language Models (LLMs) and proposes an effective detoxification approach. Prior work typically considers the Feed-Forward Network (FFN) as the main source of toxicity, representing toxic regions as a set of toxic vectors or layer-wise subspaces. However, our in-depth analysis reveals that the global toxic subspace offers a more effective and comprehensive representation of toxic region within the model. Building on this insight, we propose GloSS (Global Toxic Subspace Suppression), a lightweight, four-stage method that mitigates toxicity by identifying and removing the global toxic subspace from the parameters of FFN. Experiments across a range of LLMs show that GloSS achieves state-of-the-art detoxification performance while preserving the models general capabilities, without requiring large-scale data or model retraining.

item.title: Not Minds, but Signs: Reframing LLMs through Semiotics
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, semiotic perspective, meaning-making, interpretive acts, cultural production Summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are often framed as cognitive systems, but this paper argues for a semiotic perspective instead. LLMs are seen as agents that manipulate and circulate linguistic forms based on probabilistic associations, rather than understanding language like humans. By shifting to this framework, we avoid anthropomorphism and gain a more precise understanding of how LLMs participate in cultural processes through generating interpretive texts. LLMs can be used in literature, philosophy, education, and cultural production to facilitate creativity, dialogue, and critical inquiry. The semiotic paradigm highlights the socially embedded nature of meaning, providing a more ethically aware framework for studying and using LLMs. Ultimately, LLMs are portrayed as technological participants in the ecology of signs, influencing how we read, write, and create meaning.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17080v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This paper challenges the prevailing tendency to frame Large Language Models (LLMs) as cognitive systems, arguing instead for a semiotic perspective that situates these models within the broader dynamics of sign manipulation and meaning-making. Rather than assuming that LLMs understand language or simulate human thought, we propose that their primary function is to recombine, recontextualize, and circulate linguistic forms based on probabilistic associations. By shifting from a cognitivist to a semiotic framework, we avoid anthropomorphism and gain a more precise understanding of how LLMs participate in cultural processes, not by thinking, but by generating texts that invite interpretation. Through theoretical analysis and practical examples, the paper demonstrates how LLMs function as semiotic agents whose outputs can be treated as interpretive acts, open to contextual negotiation and critical reflection. We explore applications in literature, philosophy, education, and cultural production, emphasizing how LLMs can serve as tools for creativity, dialogue, and critical inquiry. The semiotic paradigm foregrounds the situated, contingent, and socially embedded nature of meaning, offering a more rigorous and ethically aware framework for studying and using LLMs. Ultimately, this approach reframes LLMs as technological participants in an ongoing ecology of signs. They do not possess minds, but they alter how we read, write, and make meaning, compelling us to reconsider the foundations of language, interpretation, and the role of artificial systems in the production of knowledge.

item.title: GemMaroc: Unlocking Darija Proficiency in LLMs with Minimal Data
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Moroccan Arabic, large language models, Darija, cross-lingual reasoning, GemMaroc Summary: Open-source large language models often do not adequately support Moroccan Arabic (Darija), leading to the need for complex adaptations. This study introduces a strategy to efficiently align Darija with large language models while maintaining cross-lingual reasoning skills. By translating compact instruction suites into Darija and training models with a quality-over-quantity approach, the researchers successfully enhance Darija language understanding and commonsense reasoning abilities. The resulting model, GemMaroc-27B, performs competitively on Darija language tasks and surpasses existing models on Darija commonsense challenges. Importantly, GemMaroc-27B retains strong mathematical and general reasoning capabilities while being trained in a significantly reduced amount of compute time. This approach demonstrates a sustainable and inclusive pathway for developing language technology that supports minority languages like Darija. Code, data, and checkpoints are released to encourage the development of Darija-focused applications in various domains.

Summary:
arXiv:2505.17082v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Open-source large language models (LLMs) still marginalise Moroccan Arabic (Darija), forcing practitioners either to bolt on heavyweight Arabic adapters or to sacrifice the very reasoning skills that make LLMs useful. We show that a rigorously quality-over-quantity alignment strategy can surface fluent Darija while safeguarding the backbone s cross-lingual reasoning at a sliver of the usual compute. We translate three compact instruction suites LIMA 1 K, DEITA 6 K and TULU 50 K into Darija, preserve 20 of the English originals, and add mathematics, coding and scientific prompts. A LoRA-tuned Gemma 3-4B trained on 5 K mixed instructions lifts DarijaMMLU from 32.8 to 42.7 ; adding the reasoning-dense TULU portion pushes it to 47.5 with no English regression. Scaling the identical recipe to Gemma 3-27B produces GemMaroc-27B, which matches Atlas-Chat on DarijaMMLU (61.6 ) and leaps ahead on Darija commonsense, scoring 60.5 on HellaSwag versus Atlas-Chat s 48.4 . Crucially, GemMaroc retains Gemma-27B s strong maths and general-reasoning ability, showing only minimal movement on GSM8K and English benchmarks. The entire model is trained in just 48 GPU.h, underscoring a Green AI pathway to inclusive, sustainable language technology. We release code, data and checkpoints to spur Darija-centric applications in education, public services and everyday digital interaction.

item.title: Scale-invariant Attention
item.content:encoded:
<div> scale-invariant attention, long context, LLM research, attention mechanisms, generalization
Summary: scale-invariant total attention and scale-invariant attention sparsity are two crucial conditions for effective long-context attention mechanisms. A position-dependent transformation of attention logits under a Gaussian assumption can ensure these conditions are met. Experimental results show that this scale-invariant attention scheme provides significant improvements in validation loss when transitioning from training on short contexts to validation on longer contexts, and is effective for long-context retrieval in Language Model research. <div> arXiv:2505.17083v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: One persistent challenge in LLM research is the development of attention mechanisms that are able to generalise from training on shorter contexts to inference on longer contexts. We propose two conditions that we expect all effective long context attention mechanisms to have: scale-invariant total attention, and scale-invariant attention sparsity. Under a Gaussian assumption, we show that a simple position-dependent transformation of the attention logits is sufficient for these conditions to hold. Experimentally we find that the resulting scale-invariant attention scheme gives considerable benefits in terms of validation loss when zero-shot generalising from training on short contexts to validation on longer contexts, and is effective at long-context retrieval.

item.title: Reinforcing Question Answering Agents with Minimalist Policy Gradient Optimization
item.content:encoded:
Multi-hop QA, LLMs, Mujica, MyGO, reinforcement learning
Summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) are versatile but struggle with factual knowledge in Question Answering tasks. Mujica, a Multi-hop Joint Intelligence system, decomposes questions into subquestions and resolves them via retrieval and reasoning. MyGO, a novel reinforcement learning method, enhances training efficiency by sampling trajectories from an optimal policy. This approach eliminates the need for gradient rescaling and reference models, leading to stable and effective multi-hop QA performance for various LLMs. Empirical results across datasets validate Mujica-MyGO's scalability and resource efficiency for complex QA tasks.
arXiv:2505.17086v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable versatility, due to the lack of factual knowledge, their application to Question Answering (QA) tasks remains hindered by hallucination. While Retrieval-Augmented Generation mitigates these issues by integrating external knowledge, existing approaches rely heavily on in-context learning, whose performance is constrained by the fundamental reasoning capabilities of LLMs. In this paper, we propose Mujica, a Multi-hop Joint Intelligence for Complex Question Answering, comprising a planner that decomposes questions into a directed acyclic graph of subquestions and a worker that resolves questions via retrieval and reasoning. Additionally, we introduce MyGO (Minimalist policy Gradient Optimization), a novel reinforcement learning method that replaces traditional policy gradient updates with Maximum Likelihood Estimation (MLE) by sampling trajectories from an asymptotically optimal policy. MyGO eliminates the need for gradient rescaling and reference models, ensuring stable and efficient training. Empirical results across multiple datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of Mujica-MyGO in enhancing multi-hop QA performance for various LLMs, offering a scalable and resource-efficient solution for complex QA tasks.

item.title: Informatics for Food Processing
item.content:encoded:
<div> Keywords: food processing, machine learning, artificial intelligence, data science, food informatics
Summary: This chapter delves into the evolution and health implications of food processing, with a focus on the role of machine learning, artificial intelligence (AI), and data science in advancing the field of food informatics. Traditional classification frameworks such as NOVA, Nutri-Score, and SIGA are critiqued for their subjectivity and reproducibility challenges. To address these issues, novel computational approaches such as FoodProX, a random forest model, and large language models like BERT and BioBERT are introduced. A case study using the Open Food Facts database demonstrates how multimodal AI models can integrate structured and unstructured data to classify foods at scale, offering a new approach to food processing assessment in public health and research. <div> arXiv:2505.17087v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This chapter explores the evolution, classification, and health implications of food processing, while emphasizing the transformative role of machine learning, artificial intelligence (AI), and data science in advancing food informatics. It begins with a historical overview and a critical review of traditional classification frameworks such as NOVA, Nutri-Score, and SIGA, highlighting their strengths and limitations, particularly the subjectivity and reproducibility challenges that hinder epidemiological research and public policy. To address these issues, the chapter presents novel computational approaches, including FoodProX, a random forest model trained on nutrient composition data to infer processing levels and generate a continuous FPro score. It also explores how large language models like BERT and BioBERT can semantically embed food descriptions and ingredient lists for predictive tasks, even in the presence of missing data. A key contribution of the chapter is a novel case study using the Open Food Facts database, showcasing how multimodal AI models can integrate structured and unstructured data to classify foods at scale, offering a new paradigm for food processing assessment in public health and research.

item.title: Trust Me, I Can Handle It: Self-Generated Adversarial Scenario Extrapolation for Robust Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, Safety risks, Adversarial Scenario Extrapolation, Chain-of-Thought reasoning, Robustness Summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) are powerful but face various safety risks such as jailbreaks, toxic content, hallucinations, and bias. Traditional defenses are often limited in addressing these risks and may sacrifice user experience. This paper introduces Adversarial Scenario Extrapolation (ASE), a new framework that uses Chain-of-Thought reasoning to enhance LLM robustness and seamlessness. ASE guides the LLM to consider potential adversarial scenarios and formulate defensive strategies before generating a response, leading to near-zero jailbreak attack success rates and minimal toxicity. Evaluation on multiple benchmarks showcases ASE's superiority over existing defenses in achieving high accuracy on adversarial Q&A and reducing bias. By integrating adversarial perception into the LLM's cognitive process, ASE sets a new standard for secure and natural human-AI interaction.

Summary: Large Language Models (LLMs) face safety risks like jailbreaks, toxic content, and bias. Adversarial Scenario Extrapolation (ASE) uses Chain-of-Thought reasoning to enhance LLM robustness and seamlessness, reducing jailbreak attacks and toxicity. ASE outperforms existing defenses in accuracy on adversarial Q&A and addressing bias, transforming human-AI interactions.
arXiv:2505.17089v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) exhibit impressive capabilities, but remain susceptible to a growing spectrum of safety risks, including jailbreaks, toxic content, hallucinations, and bias.
